taskDescription: An artist creates a glass paperweight. They decide they want to box and ship the paperweight, so they measure and determine that the volume of the cubic box is 125,000 mm<sup>3</sup>. Does their calculation make sense? Explain your answer.
detailedSolution:
Yes. The unit of value, mm<sup>3</sup>, may be appropriate given the size of the paperweight. The volume of 125,000 mm<sup>3</sup> is equivalent to a volume of 125 cm<sup>3</sup>, which would represent a cubic box with dimensions of
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mn>5</mn>
  <mspace width="thinmathspace"></mspace>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <mtext>cm</mtext>
  </mrow>
  <mo>×<!-- × --></mo>
  <mn>5</mn>
  <mspace width="thinmathspace"></mspace>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <mtext>cm</mtext>
  </mrow>

  <mn>5</mn>
  <mspace width="thinmathspace"></mspace>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <mtext>cm</mtext>
  </mrow>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">5\,{\text{cm}}\times 5\,{\text{cm}} \times 5\,{\text{cm}}</annotation></semantics></math>.
